intains a written emergency procedure, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The procedures are for the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs. Employees receive training in emergency procedures.  The emergency procedure is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the plant facilities.

The overall emergency procedure program for the Enterprise Thompsonville Gas Plant is coordinated with the Jim Hogg County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials and industry representatives.  The Enterprise Thompsonville Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. The remote location of the plant and limited capability of the local fire department to respond to hydrocarbon fires make any on-site response to fire suppression unlikely.  In most cases, local emergency response is expected to be limited to access and traffic control, and emergency medical evacuation, if necessary.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Thompsonville Gas Plant resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process.  Other recommendations for possible changes to improve safety come from periodic accident prevention program audits, incident investigations, or employee suggestions and recommendations.  The following changes are planned for implementation at the Thompsonville Gas Plant.

* No changes are planned.

Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP covered processes at Thompsonville Gas Plant.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features

The Thompsonville Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help contain/control a release, to quickly detect a release and reduce the consequence of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered processes:

Release Detection

* Hydrocarbon (hazardous gas) detectors and alarms
* Flame detection equipment in the storage and loading areas
* Terminal video surveillance system

Release Containment and Control

* Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated).
* Automatic shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high pressure).
* Redundant equipment and instrumentation where advisable
* Atmospheric relief devices
* Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases.
* Dual mechanical seals with seal failure alarms installed on hydrocarbon liquid pumps, where feasible.
* Secondary containment (curb and dikes) to contain any release of liquid chemicals

Release Mitigation

* Hand-held fire extinguishers
* Personnel trained in emergency response and procedures.
* Personnel protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus, etc.)

Five Year Accident History

Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

This facility has not had an accidental release in the last five years which meets the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10.

Emergency Procedures Information

ted hydrocarbon liquids which are removed from the plant by pipeline systems.

The Thompsonville Gas Plant is regulated by Federal OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  We have entered the facility as an RMP Program Level 1 facility.

Toxics

There are no toxic materials contained on site above the threshold limits.

Flammables

The Thompsonville Gas Plant was evaluated to determine if any regulated flammable or toxic substances exceeded the threshold quantity.  Listed flammable substances which are present above the threshold quantities at the Thompsonville Gas Plant are natural gas (methane), ethane, propane, iso-butane, normal butane, iso-pentane and pentane. 

Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

The offsite consequence analysis will not be reflected in the executive summary but rather is reflected in the data components.  There are flammable substances on site and no toxic substances above the threshold quantity.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program

The following is a summary of the accidental release prevention program in place at Thompsonville Gas Plant.  The process at the facility is regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation (Program 1).  Release prevention is provided through the use of written operating procedures, employee training in written procedures, including normal operation and emergency release procedures, and in the design of safety and release prevention equipment installed at the terminal site.  In addition, a written safety program designed to comply with all applicable OSHA safety performance regulations is strictly enforced at all Enterprise facilities, including the Thompsonville Gas Plant facility.  As part of the Enterprise safety program, the facility utilizes procedures that are included in the Enterprise program, but may not specifically be required at non-PSM and/or RMP Program 1 facilities (e.g. Safe work practice training; safe work permitting and hot work permit

Executive Summary
Risk Management Plan
EPA Identifier:  1000 0010 8509

Accidental Release Prevention and Response

At Enterprise, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation
* An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
* An overview of our emergency response program
* An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Thompsonville Gas Plant located in Jim Hogg County, Texas is owned by Enterprise Hydrocarbons LP, and is operated by Enterprise Products Operating, LLC.

The Thompsonville Gas Plant is a gas liquid extraction plant consisting of a single train cryogenic turboexpander process.  The plant is designed to utilize the cryogenic turbo expander process to recover natural gas liquids from the inlet gas, and is assembled primarily from prefabricated, skid- mounted process components. Produced natural gas is delivered to the facility from a gas gathering system and inlet gas pipeline.  The plant processes the gas utilizing the installed turbo expander plant to remove recoverable natural gas liquids from the inlet gas stream. Finished products are residual natural gas and extrac
